M.P.M. Builders, L.P. v. Dwyer, 442 Mass.raw_text: M.P.M. Builders, L.P. v. Dwyer, 442 Mass. 87 (2004)
M.P.M. Builders, L.P. v. Dwyer, 442 Mass.proposition: See generally M.P.M. Builders, L.P. v. Dwyer, 442 Mass. 87 (2004) (discussing landlord obligations and tenants’ remedies); Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970) (recognizing tenants’ remedies for failures to provide habitable conditions); Restatement (Second) of Property: Landlord & Tenant §§ 5.1, 17.4 (1977).
M.P.M. Builders, L.P. v. Dwyer, 442 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion in M.P.M. Builders v. Dwyer deals exclusively with property law governing easements (dominant and servient estates, and unilateral relocation of easements by the servient owner). It does not concern landlord-tenant relationships, habitability, landlord obligations, or tenants’ remedies. Citing this case as discussing landlord obligations and tenants’ remedies is therefore inaccurate and not supported by the holding or reasoning.
M.P.M. Builders, L.P. v. Dwyer, 442 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We are asked to decide whether the owner of a servient estate may change the location of an easement without the consent of the easement holder. We conclude that, subject to certain limitations, described below, the servient estate owner may do so.… The owner of the servient estate is in possession of the estate burdened by the easement. An easement is created to serve a particular objective, not to grant the easement holder the power to veto other uses of the servient estate that do not interfere with that purpose.”

Laws ch. 239 (Summary process.proposition: Authorities cited above are representative of the legal framework governing landlord obligations and tenant remedies in Massachusetts landlord‑tenant law, including the common‑law covenant of quiet enjoyment, Massachusetts statutes and regulations addressing habitability and public health, and leading authorities on landlord‑tenant remedies.
